race.name: Dead Swede Gravel
race.tagline: Northern Wyoming high plains gravel in Sheridan ranch country.

climate.description: High plains conditions with variable weather and wind.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through ranch country with Bighorn Mountains backdrop. Moderate elevation with open terrain.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Small grassroots Wyoming event. Remote ranch country setting but very limited infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: Dead Swede Gravel is a small grassroots gravel race in northern Wyoming ranch country. Sheridan is a small city with decent amenities, but the race itself is a tiny regional event with minimal infrastructure. The high plains scenery with Bighorn Mountains backdrop is beautiful, but it's remote with a small field and basic organization.
weaknesses: Small field with no competitive depth
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A small local gravel race in remote Wyoming ranch country. Perfect for locals or those seeking a Wyoming high plains experience. Not worth the long drive for most riders unless you're combining with Wyoming tourism.

final_verdict.one_liner: Small grassroots Wyoming ranch country ride with remote location.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Only if you're in Wyoming or seeking a remote high plains experience. Not worth traveling far for.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Wyoming events: other regional events. For similar ranch country vibes: Montana or Colorado high plains events.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Sheridan has basic lodging. Small city with limited options.
logistics.food: Small city with basic dining. Stock up beforehand.

history.origin_story: Grassroots gravel event in northern Wyoming ranch country.

course_description.character: High plains gravel through ranch country with mountain views.
course_description.signature_challenge: Wyoming high plains wind and open terrain.

non_negotiables.why: Wyoming high plains means significant wind exposure.
Remote location and minimal support mean managing your own nutrition and mechanicals.

topics.wind: Riding in Wyoming high plains wind

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of Wyoming high plains gravel in ranch country.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Small grassroots event in remote Sheridan.

logistics.explanation: Packet pickup requires day-before arrival only, which Anonymous notes 'pretty much requires that participants book some form of lodging for one night.' Registration via ItsYourRace works fine, and one rider confirms the process 'from registration to packet pickup to post meal collection was seamless.' Still no airport or parking details published. As Heidi puts it: "all done on a 2012 Specialized Crux with canti brakes and relatively narrow tires in comparison to today's trends, and hamburger seat bag. I thumb my nose at you, industry marketing tactics!"

length.explanation: Heidi finished the 40-mile course in 2:26 after 'a solo time trial effort over most of the course,' placing 13th overall out of 330+ racers. Jeffrey's 100-mile took 8:45 total time with 'about 1.5 hours before the DNF cutoff' at the final aid station. Multiple distances accommodate different ambitions without overwhelming terrain. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Heidi puts it: "2nd place overall women, 2nd place 30-49 women, 13th place overall out of 330 or so racers. 2 hours and 26 minutes..."

technicality.explanation: Heidi successfully descended at 43mph on loose gravel using a 2012 cyclocross bike with cantilever brakes and 32mm tires, noting 'I railed the descents.' Jeffrey describes one climb as '9-12% max grade for about a quarter mile' marked with a 'can we still be friends' sign. Challenging but manageable on standard gravel setups. Less technical than The Mid South. As Heidi puts it: "8 miles of pavement to get us warmed up... After eight miles we hit the gravel and immediately the first big climb of the day."

elevation.explanation: The 100-mile course climbs to 6,516 feet with Jeffrey noting 'long grindy uphills' throughout his 103-mile route. Heidi describes the 40-mile as starting with 'eight miles of pavement to get us warmed up' before hitting 'the first big climb of the day' immediately on gravel. Steady climbing without soul-crushing mega-ascents. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds. As Jeffrey Cory puts it: "The picture of the 'can we still be friends' sign is from the steepest hill, near the top. I'd say it was 9-12% max grade for about a quarter mile."

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 79°F and lows of 53°F, with a 41% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 27 mph. Weather swings wildly year to year. Heidi's 2019 race was blazing hot: 'The still air combined with my black skin suit and hot sun made me want to melt.' Jeffrey's 2022 featured 'amazing weather, low 50s to start, mid 70s in afternoon' but rain dumped 2.5 inches the day before, forcing course changes. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Heidi puts it: "Around hour one I started sipping my Tailwind, cognizant of the fact I needed to be taking on the calories and hydration in the sun."

altitude.explanation: Starting from Sheridan at ~3,800 feet and climbing toward the Bighorn Mountain foothills, Jeffrey's 100-mile reached 6,516 feet maximum elevation. Sea-level riders will notice the thinner air but won't need oxygen therapy. High enough to affect performance, manageable enough to keep racing. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

adventure.explanation: The course turns 'north onto the gravel nestled along the base of the Bighorn Mountains' with minimal dust conditions, possibly from road oil treatment or recent rain. One rider loved starting 'at Kendrick Park, right there in the heart of town' with horses 'grazing on the hillside overlooking the park.' Wyoming backcountry through terrain most never see. As Jeffrey Cory puts it: "my passion is bikepacking, and many of those long miles are solo, so the beautiful landscape (see pics) and sky kept me company."

prestige.explanation: Jeffrey finished 64th out of 65 finishers in the 100-mile, spending most of the race dead last with a sweeper truck following him. Heidi notes the mass start crowd was 'mostly filled with people that have never road raced or ridden in a peloton.' Self-proclaimed 'Premier Gravel Race of the West' without competitive depth to support the claim.

race_quality.explanation: Aid stations every 10-12 miles offer pickle juice shots, bacon, and PBR with volunteers providing 'cheers and cowbells and offers to feed me' according to Jeffrey. Course changes happen when weather demands it - the single-track mountain section was eliminated in 2022 due to snow. Functional organization with weather flexibility. As Jeffrey Cory puts it: "a black truck ('race support,' aka, Dead Swede sag wagon, aka, the one who makes you get in for a ride home when you don't make the time cutoffs) literally, and I mean literally, followed me (I'll giv..."

experience.explanation: Heidi finished prouder than she'd 'been in a long time, or even never' after her second-place women's finish. The finish line features 'cheering crowds, a band in the amphitheater, and the smell of delicious barbecue' with free race beer. Solid Wyoming gravel touring without standout memorable moments. As Jeffrey Cory puts it: "my passion is bikepacking, and many of those long miles are solo, so the beautiful landscape (see pics) and sky kept me company."

community.explanation: The event 'has crazy huge women's fields' per Heidi, with 330+ riders in just the 40-mile distance. Aid station volunteers 'got all whoop-y and jumpy' when they realized Jeffrey was attempting the full 100-mile. Organizers ban course support vehicles 'for rider safety, and to minimize dust' creating a more controlled racing environment. As Jeffrey Cory puts it: "I went under the finish banner just as they were getting the afternoon podium awards going. Kind of ironic. Or something... Yeah, the free race beer at the finish party tasted pretty good."

field_depth.explanation: Jeffrey rode 'almost all of the hundred miles solo' and was 'In. Fact. DFL' by mile 20, finishing 64th of 65 riders with a sweeper truck escort. While field sizes reach 330+ in shorter distances, competitive depth remains shallow. Large participation numbers don't translate to racing quality at the sharp end. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Heidi puts it: "2nd place overall women, 2nd place 30-49 women, 13th place overall out of 330 or so racers. 2 hours and 26 minutes..."

value.explanation: $100 entry includes Dead Swede t-shirt, sticker, and pint glass with well-stocked aid stations every 10-12 miles featuring bacon and beer. Free finish line barbecue, live band, and race beer complete the package. Solid bang for buck accessing Bighorn Mountain foothills terrain that would cost serious gas money to explore solo.

expenses.explanation: Sheridan, Wyoming keeps lodging and dining costs reasonable, though day-before packet pickup 'pretty much requires' overnight accommodation. The $100 entry fee won't strain anyone's budget. Equipment needs stay modest - Heidi succeeded on a 2012 cyclocross bike with narrow tires, proving expensive gravel setups aren't required. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
